property.description:
• Utilization (%) :100 * (Busy Ticks/s) / (Busy Ticks/s + Idle Ticks/s) Percentage of time that the SP was busy serving incoming requests. Busy Ticks/s: Number of ticks (1 tick = 100 ms) that occurred when this LUN was busy. Idle Ticks/s: Number of ticks (1 tick = 100 ms) that occurred when this LUN was idle.
  • Queue Length: (Average Busy Queue Length) * (% Utilization) Average number of requests that are waiting while the SP is busy, including the current request in service.
  • Average Busy Queue Length: (Sum Queue Lengths - Number Arrivals With Non Zero Queue / 2) / (Read Throughput [IO/s] + Write Throughput [IO/s]) Sum Queue Lengths: Number of requests waiting for the disk within a time interval, including the current request in service. Number Arrivals With Non Zero Queue: Number of times that a user request arrived while at least one other request was being processed.

parameter.name: subtract metric
parameter.result: Number Arrivals With Non Zero Queue / 2

result.name: Number Arrivals With Non Zero Queue / 2

property.description: Hard/Soft Errors: Through the service processor, the array proactively monitors all end-to-end I/O operations for errors and faults. By tracking there errors during nirmal operation, the Array can recognize patterns of error activity and predict a potential hard failure. This proactive error tracking capability can fence off, or remove from service, a suspect component before a failure occurs. When such errors are detected, the Array performs diagnostic tests to determine if the component has experienced a hard or soft failure. In the event of a hard failure (disk error), the component is fenced off. In the event of a soft error (such as memory error, cache error, alpja-particle-onduced single-bit error, …), the Array logs the error, corrects the data, and continues to operate with that. If the soft error rate exceeds a preset threshold, the Array fences the component for replacement.

• Queue Length : The average number of requests within a polling interval that are outstanding to this LUN.
  • Service Time (ms) : Average time, in milliseconds, that the LUN spends servicing a request. This does not include any time waiting in a queue.
  • Response Time (ms) : The average time, in milliseconds, that a request to this LUN is outstanding, including its waiting time.
  • Bandwidth (KB/s) :The average amount of host data in Mbytes that is passed through the LUN per second. This includes both read and write requests.
  • IOPS ou Total Throughput (I/O/sec) : The average number of host requests that is passed through the LUN per second. This includes both read and write requests.
  • Capacity : The total capacity of the specific LUN
  • Availability : This provide the current availability of the LUN. It is either up of down.
  • Utilization (%) :This provides the current busy states of the LUN.

property.description: Used Prefetches : This measure is an indication of prefetching efficiency. To improve real bandwidth , two consecutive requests trigger prefetching,thereby filling the read cache with data before it is requested. Thus sequential requests will receive the data from the read cache instead of from the disks, which results in a lower response time and higher throughput. As the precentage of sequential requests rises,so does the percentage of used prefetches.

property.displayedProperties: parttype[Storage Pool Type] part[Name] dgraid[RAID Type]

property.description:
• Raw Capacity : This shows the raw capacity of the Raid Group (sum of disks space).
  • Usable capacity : This provides the total space available across that Raid Group.
  • Free capacity : This provides the total space that is not allocated to LUNs

• Raw Capacity : This shows the raw capacity of the RAID Group (sum of disks space).
  • Usable capacity : This provides the total space available across that RAID Group.
  • Allocated capacity : This provides the total space used by LUNs across that RAID Group.
  • Free capacity : This provides the total space that is not allocated to LUNs
  • Number of LUNs : This shows the number of LUNs across that RAID Group.
  • RAID Group IOPS : This provides the current IOPS of the RAID Group. This is the sum of all drive IOPS within the RAID Group.

• Raw Capacity Total: This is the total of all disks capacity.
  • Raw Capacity Free : Total of disks capacity for disks that do not belong to a RAID Group or a Storage Pool (Unbound disks).
  • Usable Capacity : Total usable space in the Storage Pool or RAID Group.
  • Logical Free Capacity : Total free capacity in the Storage Pool or RAID Group.
  • Element (SP, Disk, Lun) In Problem: The number of element in problem. An element is in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization

This report displays a summary for each array components

  • Storage Processor: The Storage Processor (SP) processes all I/Os within the storage system, host requests, management and maintenance tasks, as well as operations related to replication or migration features.
  • Disk: As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.
  • LUN:A LUN is an abstract object whose performance depends on various factors. The main aspect is whether a host I/O can get satisfied by the cache or not. A cache hit does not require any disk access; a cache miss however requires one or more disk accesses to complete the data request. Most cache statistics are available only for the LUN object.

The total IOPS is the sum of IOPS for each disks belonging to the raid group.

The Raid Group potential IOPS is the sum of IOPS limitation for each disks belonging to it. For example, assume a single 15k rpm Fibre Channel hard drive is capable of about 180 IOPS. For a 4 disks RAID5(3+1), data is spread across all 4 drives. This raid group has a potential throughput of 720 IOPS (180*4).

The percentage is the ratio between the total and the potential IOPS. You should not do final performance planning on the basis of this type of calculation. It is not possible to accurately calculate the Raid group's performance without knowing the characteristics of its IO. (Mirror-type RAID, for instance)

RAID Read / Write IOPS Capability (or Potential Read / Write Disks IOPS) is the theoretical read / write IOPS capability of a RAID Group (or array). For example, assume a single 15k rpm Fibre Channel hard drive is capable of about 180 IOPS. For a 5 drives RAID5(4+1), data is spread across all 4 drives (one is kept for parity). This raid group has a potential read throughput of 720 IOPS (180*4) and a maximum write IOPS to 225 ((5*180)/4).

  • RAID Read IOPS Capability : The total potential of disks read IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Read IOPS = ( Number of disks in Array - 1 ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array
  • Total Read IOPS : The total Raid Groups read IOPS

• Read Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host read data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host write data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Read Throughput (I/O/sec): The average number of host read requests that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Throughput (I/O/sec): The average number of host write requests that is passed through the SP per second.

RAID Read / Write IOPS Capability (or Potential Read / Write Disks IOPS) is the theoretical read / write IOPS capability of a RAID Group (or array). For example, assume a single 15k rpm Fibre Channel hard drive is capable of about 180 IOPS. For a 5 drives RAID5(4+1), data is spread across all 4 drives (one is kept for parity). This raid group has a potential read throughput of 720 IOPS (180*4) and a maximum write IOPS to 225 ((5*180)/4).

  • RAID Read IOPS Capability : The total potential of disks read IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Read IOPS = ( Number of disks in Array - 1 ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array
  • Total Read IOPS : The total Raid Groups read IOPS

• Read Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host read data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host write data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Read Throughput (I/O/sec): The average number of host read requests that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Throughput (I/O/sec): The average number of host write requests that is passed through the SP per second.

An important SP performance metric is SP Utilization. Ideally, in a production environment with strict requirements for high availability and consistent performance, the SP CPU utilization should be around 50 percent. This way, if an failure triggers an SP failover, the peer SP can easily accommodate its own processing load and the failed-over load. When the SP becomes the bottleneck, the utilization will be at or close to 100%. An increase in workload will have no further impact on the SP throughput, but the I/O response time will start increasing more aggressively.


  • Utilization (%): The percentage of time during which the SP is servicing any request.
  • Response Time (ms): The average time, in milliseconds, that a request to a SP is outstanding, including waiting time. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.
  • Service Time (ms) : Average time, in milliseconds, that the SP spends servicing a request. This does not include any time waiting in a queue. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.

property.displayedProperties: device[Array] part[SP name] partip[SP IP] partsn[Serial Number] partvrs[Revision]
property.description:
• Utilization (%): Percentage of time that the SP was busy serving incoming requests.
  • Write Cache Utilization Cache utilization is the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark. High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark), and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.
  • Queue Length: The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An average queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If 3 requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time ,only one of them can be served immediatly; the other 2 must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of 3.
  • Flush Ratio (%) The fraction number of flush operations performed vs. the number of write requests. A flush operation is a write of a portion of the cache to make room for incoming write data. Since the ratio is a measure for the backend activity versus the frontend activity, a lower number indicates better performance.
  • Bandwidth and Throughput:
    • Read Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host read data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
    • Write Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host write data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
    • Total Throughput (IO/s): The average number of host requests that is passed through the SP per second. This includes both, read and write requests.
    • Read Throughput (IO/s): The average number of host read requests that is passed through the SP per second.
    • Write Throughput (IO/s): The average number of host write requests that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Cache Flushes/s : Number of I/O operations written each second from cache to the SP.
  • Response Time (ms): The average time in milliseconds that it takes for one request to pass through the SP, including any waiting time.
  • Service Time (ms): Average time, in milliseconds, that the SP spends servicing a request. This does not include any time waiting in a queue.

Utilization (%):
Percentage of time that the SP was busy serving incoming requests. Typically 100 * (Busy Ticks/s) / (Busy Ticks/s + Idle Ticks/s)

Write Cache Utilization
Cache utilization is the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark. High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark, and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.
• Service Time (ms): Average time, in milliseconds, that the SP spends servicing a request. This does not include any time waiting in a queue.

Queue Length:
The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An average queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If 3 requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time ,only one of them can be served immediatly; the other 2 must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of 3.

Flush Ratio (%)
The fraction number of flush operations performed vs. the number of write requests. A flush operation is a write of a portion of the cache to make room for incoming write data. Since the ratio is a measure for the backend activity versus the frontend activity, a lower number indicates better performance.

• Read Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host read data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host write data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Total Throughput (IO/sec): The average number of host requests that is passed through the SP per second. This includes both, read and write requests.
  • Read Throughput (IO/sec): The average number of host read requests that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Throughput (IO/sec): The average number of host write requests that is passed through the SP per second.

• Read Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host read data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Bandwidth (MB/s): The average amount of host write data in Mbytes that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Read Throughput (IO/s): The average number of host read requests that is passed through the SP per second.
  • Write Throughput (IO/s): The average number of host write requests that is passed through the SP per second.

Write Cache Flushes/s :
Number of I/O operations written each second from cache to the SP.
• Response Time (ms): The average time in milliseconds that it takes for one request to pass through the SP, including any waiting time.

LUN: a LUN is an abstract object whose performance depends on various factors. The main aspect is whether a host I/O can get satisfied by the cache or not. A cache hit does not require any disk access; a cache miss however requires one or more disk accesses to complete the data request. Most cache statistics are available only for the LUN object.


  • Current Highest Utilization (%): The highest percentage of the fraction of an observation period during which a LUN has any outstanding requests.
  • LUNs In Problem: The number of LUNs in problem. A LUN is in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization
• LUNs:This shows the number of LUNs across all RAID Groups except spare RAID Groups

Disk: As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.


  • Current Highest Disk Utilization (%): The highest percentage of time all disks are servicing requests.
  • Disk In Problem: The number of disk in problem. A disk is considered in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization
  • Raw Capacity : This is the sum of Raw Capacity for each disks belonging to this array.

As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.


  • Utilization (%) : The percentage of time during which the disk is servicing any requests.
  • Queue Length :The average number of requests within a polling interval that are waiting to be serviced by the disk, including the one currently in service.
  • Service Time (ms) : Average time, in milliseconds, that the disk spends servicing a request. This time does not include any waiting time. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.
  • Response Time (ms) : The average time, in milliseconds, that it takes for one request to pass through the disk, including any waiting time. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.
  • Bandwidth (KB/s) : The average amount of data in Mbytes that is transferred to or from the disk per second. Total bandwidth includes both, read and write requests.
  • IOPS : The average number of requests to the disk per second. Total throughput includes both, read and write requests.

Ratio of the largest number of contiguous unallocated bytes to the total amount of free memory.

For example, a value of 5 indicates that the largest free buffer is 5% of the free memory.

A value under 5% could indicate a memory fragmentation problem: which could result from a process that has consumed a large amount of processor memory and then released most or all of it, leaving fragments of memory still allocated either by this process or by other processes that allocated memory during the same period. If the same event occurs several times, the memory may fragment into very small blocks, to the point where all processes requiring a larger block of memory could not get the amount of memory that they need.

Recommended actions:

  • Add more memory
  • Shut down some interfaces which may release the fragmented blocks.
  • Contact your Cisco support representative.

Ratio of the largest number of contiguous unallocated bytes to the total amount of free memory.

For example, a value of 5 indicates that the largest free buffer is 5% of the free memory.

A value under 5% could indicate a memory fragmentation problem: meaning that a process has consumed a large amount of processor memory and then released most or all of it, leaving fragments of memory still allocated either by this process, or by other processes that allocated memory during the problem. If the same event occurs several times, the memory may fragment into very small blocks, to the point where all processes requiring a larger block of memory cannot get the amount of memory that they need.

Recommended actions:

  • Add more memory
  • Shut down some interfaces which may release the fragmented blocks.
  • Contact your Cisco support representative.

property.description:
This report displays the summary of the Health of a device.
  • High values for the Health Factor are better.
  • The Health Factor is based on the Availability and the utilization of each of the devices' interface as well as the memory and CPU utilization.

High Usage.

The following file systems are excluded from this report:

  • /dev/*
  • /devices/*
  • /proc/*
  • /devices/*
  • /vol/*
  • /sys/*
  • /system/*

File systems that are below the 80% usage threshold will not appear in this report.

node.name: FAST Cache Read and Write Hits/s

property.description: Average number of write requests per second that were satisfied by FAST Cache. In other words, the drive I/O went to the FAST Cache drives, not the LUN's Pool or RAID group.

node.name: FAST Cache Read and Write Misses/s

property.description: Average number of write requests per second that were not satisfied by FAST Cache. In other words, the I/O went to the LUN's Pool or RAID group drives. This would occur for all blocks not promoted into FAST Cache.

node.name: FAST Cache Read and Write Hit Ratio
FAST Cache Dirty Pages (%) - SP level

property.description: A measure of the amount of FAST Cache that has been written to more recently than the original LUNs. The "clean" I/O, where the copies of the block on the Storage Pool and the FAST Cache match is not counted in this percentage. This is not a measure of the amount of data in FAST Cache because FAST Cache % full would be both the clean and the dirty pages. Unisphere does not track the total amount of data in FAST Cache and it is assumed to be nearly full at all times when it is enabled.

node.name: FAST Cache MBs Flushed (MB/s) - SP level

property.description: The rate at which the dirty pages (or blocks) on the FAST Cache drives are copied back to the original LUNs. Once each page has been written back to the original LUN, this page is considered "clean," until the FAST Cache page is written to again.

node.name: Array vs FAST Cache Write IOPS

Read / Write IOPS Capability (or Potential Read / Write Disks IOPS) is the theoretical read / write IOPS capability. For example, assume a single 15k rpm Fibre Channel hard drive is capable of about 180 IOPS. For a 5 drives RAID5(4+1), data is spread across all 4 drives (one is kept for parity). This Storarge Pool has a potential read throughput of 720 IOPS (180*4) and a maximum write IOPS to 225 ((5*180)/4).

  • Read IOPS Capability : The potential of disks read IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Read IOPS = ( Number of disks in Array - 1 ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array
  • Write IOPS Capability : The potential of disks write IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Write IOPS = ( ( Number of disks in Array ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array / (4 ) )
  • Disks Read Busy (%) : This is a ratio of all disks read requests (ReadRequests KPI) with the Storage Pool read IOPS limitation.
  • Disks Write Busy (%) : This is a ratio of all disks write requests (WriteRequests KPI) with the Storage Pool write IOPS limitation.

IMPORTANT: The disks write / read / total busy percentage can exceed the value of 100.

RAID Read / Write IOPS Capability (or Potential Read / Write Disks IOPS) is the theoretical read / write IOPS capability of a RAID Group (or array). For example, assume a single 15k rpm Fibre Channel hard drive is capable of about 180 IOPS. For a 5 drives RAID5(4+1), data is spread across all 4 drives (one is kept for parity). This raid group has a potential read throughput of 720 IOPS (180*4) and a maximum write IOPS to 225 ((5*180)/4).

  • RAID Read IOPS Threshold : The potential of disks read IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Read IOPS = ( Number of disks in Array - 1 ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array
  • RAID Write IOPS Threshold : The potential of disks write IOPS regarding the RAID configuration (Array). RAID5 Write IOPS = ( ( Number of disks in Array ) x IOPS Per Disk in Array / ( 4 ) )
  • Disks Read Busy (%) : This is a ratio of all disks read requests (ReadRequests KPI) with the raid group read IOPS limitation.
  • Disks Write Busy (%) : This is a ratio of all disks write requests (WriteRequests KPI) with the raid group write IOPS limitation.

IMPORTANT: The disks write / read / total busy percentage can exceed the value of 100.

node.name: LUN Utilization and SP Queue Length

property.description:
Queue Length:
The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An average queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If 3 requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time ,only one of them can be served immediatly; the other 2 must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of 3.

property.description: Dirty Page or Write Cache Utilization The % of cache pages owned by the storage processor that was modified since it was last read from , or written to, disk. In an optimal environment, the dirty pages % will not exceed the high watermark for a long period.

The % of cache pages owned by the storage processor that was modified since it was last read from , or writtento, disk. In an optimal environment, the dirty pages % will not exceed the high watermark for a long period.

This report displays the number of time the dirty pages % exceeds the threshold (80%). The Over High Watermark (%) is the percentage of values over the threshold. The Over Hw Total Duration is the sum of duration the dirty pages metric exceeds the threshold.

property.name: Over Threshold Duration (s) - avg. over period
Over Threshold Watermark (%) - avg. over period

property.description:
Write Cache Utilization
The black line is cache utilization, or the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark (red line). High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark (green line), and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.

Write Cache Utilization
The black line is cache utilization, or the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark (red line). High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark (green line), and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.

Flush Ratio (%)
The fraction number of flush operations performed vs. the number of write requests. A flush operation is a write of a portion of the cache to make room for incoming write data. Since the ratio is a measure for the backend activity versus the frontend activity, a lower number indicates better performance.

High watermark flush on rate is the number of times that the number of modified pages in the write cache reached the high watermark. The higher the number, the greater the write workload coming from the host.

Low watermark flush off rate is the number of times that the number of modified pages in the write cache reached the low watermark, at which point the storage processor stops flushing the cache. The higher the number, the greater the write workload coming from the host. This number should be close to the high watermarker flush on number.

Write Cache Utilization
The black line is cache utilization, or the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark (red line). High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark (green line), and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.

Write Cache Utilization
The black line is cache utilization, or the percentage of dirty pages. The workload's activity is shown to fill cache to the high watermark (red line). High water flushing then flushes the cache down to the low watermark (green line), and cache is allowed to fill again. No flushing occurs until the high watermark is again exceeded.

Flush Ratio (%)
The fraction number of flush operations performed vs. the number of write requests. A flush operation is a write of a portion of the cache to make room for incoming write data. Since the ratio is a measure for the backend activity versus the frontend activity, a lower number indicates better performance.

High watermark flush on rate is the number of times that the number of modified pages in the write cache reached the high watermark. The higher the number, the greater the write workload coming from the host.

Low watermark flush off rate is the number of times that the number of modified pages in the write cache reached the low watermark, at which point the storage processor stops flushing the cache. The higher the number, the greater the write workload coming from the host. This number should be close to the high watermarker flush on number.
Hit Ratio (%) The fraction of write requests served from the write cache vs. the total number of write requests to this LUN. The higher the ratio, the better the write performance.

Used Prefetches : This measure is an indication of prefetching efficiency. To improve real bandwidth , two consecutive requests trigger prefetching,thereby filling the read cache with data before it is requested. Thus sequential requests will receive the data from the read cache instead of from the disks, which results in a lower response time and higher throughput. As the precentage of sequential requests rises,so does the percentage of used prefetches.

Hit ratio (%) The fraction of read requests served from both read and write caches vs. the number of read requests to this LUN. THe higher the ratio,the better the read performance.
A list of different storage components, ordered by their I/O rate in descending order.

This report is an array dashboard displaying basic performance indicators for the following elements: RAID Group, Pools, Storage Processor, and LUN. Disks are not shown here since RAID Groups and pools are more representative.

  • Utilization (%) – The fraction of a certain observation period that the system component is busy serving incoming requests. A SP or disk that shows 100 percent (or close to 100 percent) utilization is a system bottleneck, since an increase in the overall workload will not affect the component throughput; the component has reached its saturation point. Since a LUN is considered busy if any of its disks are busy, LUN utilization usually represents a pessimistic view. That is, a high LUN utilization value does not necessarily indicate that the LUN is approaching its maximum capacity.
  • Queue length – The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An (average) queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If three requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time, only one of them can be served immediately; the other two must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of three.
  • Response time (ms) – The average time, in milliseconds, required for one request to pass through a system component, including its waiting time. The higher the queue length for a component, the more requests are waiting in its queue, thus increasing the average response time of a single request. For a given workload, queue length and response time are directly proportional.
  • Total bandwidth (MB/s) – The average amount of data in Mbytes that is passed through a system component per second. Larger requests usually result in a higher total bandwidth than smaller requests. Total bandwidth includes both read and write requests.
  • Total throughput (IO/s) – The average number of requests that pass through a system component per second. Since smaller requests need a shorter time for this, they usually result in a higher total throughput than larger requests do. Total throughput includes both read and write requests.

Note: There is no native "performance metrics" for RAID Groups but capacity information. So that, RAID Groups performance KPIs are computed as follow:
- Utilization, Queue Length, Response Time KPIs : Maximum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the RAID Group
- Total bandwidth (MB/s), Total throughput (IO/s) KPIs: Sum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the RAID Group

• Queue length – The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An (average) queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If three requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time, only one of them can be served immediately; the other two must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of three.
Note: There is no native "performance metrics" for raid groups but capacity information. So that, Raid groups performance KPIs are computed as follow:
- Utilization, Queue Length, Response Time KPIs : Maximum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group
- Total bandwidth (MB/s), Total throughput (IO/s) KPIs: Sum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group

• Queue length – The average number of requests within a certain time interval waiting to be served by the component, including the one in service. An (average) queue length of zero indicates an idle system. If three requests arrive at an empty service center at the same time, only one of them can be served immediately; the other two must wait in the queue, resulting in a queue length of three.
Note: There is no native "performance metrics" for raid groups but capacity information. So that, Raid groups performance KPIs are computed as follow:
- Utilization, Queue Length, Response Time KPIs : Maximum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group
- Total bandwidth (MB/s), Total throughput (IO/s) KPIs: Sum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group

property.description: Hard/Soft Errors: Through the service processor, the array proactively monitors all end-to-end I/O operations for errors and faults. By tracking there errors during nirmal operation, the Array can recognize patterns of error activity and predict a potential hard failure. This proactive error tracking capability can fence off, or remove from service, a suspect component before a failure occurs. When such errors are detected, the Array performs diagnostic tests to determine if the component has experienced a hard or soft failure. In the event of a hard failure (disk error), the component is fenced off. In the event of a soft error (such as memory error, cache error, alpja-particle-onduced single-bit error, …), the Array logs the error, corrects the data, and continues to operate with that. If the soft error rate exceeds a preset threshold, the Array fences the component for replacement.

Hard/Soft Errors: Through the service processor, the array proactively monitors all end-to-end I/O operations for errors and faults. By tracking there errors during nirmal operation, the Array can recognize patterns of error activity and predict a potential hard failure. This proactive error tracking capability can fence off, or remove from service, a suspect component before a failure occurs. When such errors are detected, the Array performs diagnostic tests to determine if the component has experienced a hard or soft failure. In the event of a hard failure (disk error), the component is fenced off. In the event of a soft error (such as memory error, cache error, alpja-particle-onduced single-bit error, …), the Array logs the error, corrects the data, and continues to operate with that. If the soft error rate exceeds a preset threshold, the Array fences the component for replacement.

This proactive error tracking capability can fence off, or remove from service, a suspect component before a failure occurs. When such errors are detected, the Array performs diagnostic tests to determine if the component has experienced a hard or soft failure. In the event of a hard failure (disk error), the component is fenced off. In the event of a soft error (such as memory error, cache error, alpja-particle-onduced single-bit error, …), the Array logs the error, corrects the data, and continues to operate with that. If the soft error rate exceeds a preset threshold, the Array fences the component for replacement.

property.description:
• Utilization – The fraction of a certain observation period that the system component is busy serving incoming requests. An SP or disk that shows 100 percent (or close to 100 percent) utilization is a system bottleneck, since an increase in the overall workload will not affect the component throughput; the component has reached its saturation point. Since a LUN is considered busy if any of its disks are busy, LUN utilization usually represents a pessimistic view. That is, a high LUN utilization value does not necessarily indicate that the LUN is approaching its maximum capacity.
  • Response time (ms) – The average time, in milliseconds, required for one request to pass through a system component, including its waiting time. The higher the queue length for a component, the more requests are waiting in its queue, thus increasing the average response time of a single request. For a given workload, queue length and response time are directly proportional.
  • Total bandwidth (MB/s) – The average amount of data in Mbytes that is passed through a system component per second. Larger requests usually result in a higher total bandwidth than smaller requests. Total bandwidth includes both read and write requests.
Note: There is no native "performance metrics" for raid groups but capacity information. So that, Raid groups performance KPIs are computed as follow:
- Utilization, Queue Length, Response Time KPIs : Maximum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group
- Total bandwidth (MB/s), Total throughput (IO/s) KPIs: Sum of the KPI values for each disks belonging to the raid group

property.description: Hard/Soft Errors: Through the service processor, the array proactively monitors all end-to-end I/O operations for errors and faults. By tracking there errors during normal operation, the Array can recognize patterns of error activity and predict a potential hard failure. This proactive error tracking capability can fence off, or remove from service, a suspect component before a failure occurs. When such errors are detected, the Array performs diagnostic tests to determine if the component has experienced a hard or soft failure. In the event of a hard failure (disk error), the component is fenced off. In the event of a soft error (such as memory error, cache error, alpja-particle-onduced single-bit error, …), the Array logs the error, corrects the data, and continues to operate with that. If the soft error rate exceeds a preset threshold, the Array fences the component for replacement.

• Nb. of LUNs : This shows the number of LUN inside that RAID Group
  • Raw Capacity : This shows the raw capacity of the RAID Group

This report applies only to RAID Groups, not pools. If no data is shown, defragmentation on disks is OK.
Drill down on an Array to see the heat map

• Queue Length : The average number of requests within a polling interval that are outstanding to this LUN.
  • Service Time (ms) : Average time, in milliseconds, that the LUN spends servicing a request. This does not include any time waiting in a queue.
  • Response Time (ms) : The average time, in milliseconds, that a request to this LUN is outstanding, including its waiting time.
  • Bandwidth (KB/s) :The average amount of host data in Mbytes that is passed through the LUN per second. This includes both read and write requests.
  • IOPS ou Total Throughput (I/O/sec) : The average number of host requests that is passed through the LUN per second. This includes both read and write requests.
  • Capacity : The total capacity of the specific LUN
  • Availability : This provide the current availability of the LUN. It is either up of down.
  • Utilization (%) :This provides the current busy states of the LUN.

• Raw Capacity Total: This is the total of all disks capacity.
  • Raw Capacity Free : Total of disks capacity for disks that do not belong to a RAID Group or a Storage Pool (Unbound disks).
  • Usable Capacity : Total usable space in the Storage Pool or RAID Group.
  • Logical Free Capacity : Total free capacity in the Storage Pool or RAID Group.
  • Element (SP, Disk, Lun) In Problem: The number of element in problem. An element is in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization

This report displays a summary for each array components

  • Storage Processor: The Storage Processor (SP) processes all I/Os within the storage system, host requests, management and maintenance tasks, as well as operations related to replication or migration features.
  • Disk: As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.
  • LUN:A LUN is an abstract object whose performance depends on various factors. The main aspect is whether a host I/O can get satisfied by the cache or not. A cache hit does not require any disk access; a cache miss however requires one or more disk accesses to complete the data request. Most cache statistics are available only for the LUN object.

LUN: a LUN is an abstract object whose performance depends on various factors. The main aspect is whether a host I/O can get satisfied by the cache or not. A cache hit does not require any disk access; a cache miss however requires one or more disk accesses to complete the data request. Most cache statistics are available only for the LUN object.


  • Current Highest Utilization (%): The highest percentage of the fraction of an observation period during which a LUN has any outstanding requests.
  • LUNs In Problem: The number of LUNs in problem. A LUN is in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization
• LUNs:This shows the number of LUNs across all RAID Groups except spare RAID Groups

Disk: As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.


  • Current Highest Disk Utilization (%): The highest percentage of time all disks are servicing requests.
  • Disk In Problem: The number of disk in problem. A disk is considered in problem when it exceeds 70 % of utilization
  • Raw Capacity : This is the sum of Raw Capacity for each disks belonging to this array.

As the slowest devices in a storage system, disk drives are very often responsible for performance-related issues. Therefore, we recommend that you pay close attention to disk drives when analyzing performance problems.


  • Utilization (%) : The percentage of time during which the disk is servicing any requests.
  • Queue Length :The average number of requests within a polling interval that are waiting to be serviced by the disk, including the one currently in service.
  • Service Time (ms) : Average time, in milliseconds, that the disk spends servicing a request. This time does not include any waiting time. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.
  • Response Time (ms) : The average time, in milliseconds, that it takes for one request to pass through the disk, including any waiting time. When its value is empty you need to install Navisphere Analyzer.
  • Bandwidth (KB/s) : The average amount of data in Mbytes that is transferred to or from the disk per second. Total bandwidth includes both, read and write requests.
  • IOPS : The average number of requests to the disk per second. Total throughput includes both, read and write requests.
